feed.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System

entry.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a recent discussion, front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace was addressed. Front-running refers to entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. The discussion focused on how this could occur in the context of a bulletin board operator relaying orders from makers to takers.The scenario presented involved Mary the Maker publishing a limit order to buy a derivative. Bob, the bulletin board operator, can choose to execute against Mary's order or relay it to Terry the Taker and other subscribers. Concerns were raised about Bob potentially collecting outsized profits if he has a trusted position. It was argued that if Bob only relays what he perceives as unprofitable orders, eventually takers like Terry will move to other markets.The discussion also considered comparing Bob and Terry on metrics like execution quality to draw more market activity by providing better prices. "Board monitoring" algorithms were mentioned as a way to mitigate order book risks, although specific criteria were not provided. The concept of front-running resistance in a peer-to-peer marketplace was explored, including duplicating offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitoring latency for anomalies. Running the bulletin boards as a federation with consensus mechanisms in place was suggested as another approach.It was emphasized that providing a good user experience and finding products people are interested in trading is important. Front-running was seen as a sign of active participants and liquidity, which is desirable. The paper proposed a flexible framework for peer-to-peer marketplaces where front-running resistance parameters can be adapted based on trade types and market participants' tolerance.In a separate announcement, the developers of Civ Kit shared details about the architecture of their system. They expressed gratitude to peer reviewers and plan to release code and modules gradually, leveraging the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. This aligns with the open-source and decentralized standards established by Bitcoin Core. The developers seek collaboration with the community to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients.The announcement encourages feedback from the community and includes links for further reference, including the full content of the announcement, the W3C Recommendation document for Decentralized Identifier (DID) Core, the Privacypass website, and the GitHub repository containing the paper on Civ Kit's architecture. The developers emphasize their commitment to open collaboration, adherence to standards, and willingness to receive feedback.
